review.title: The Algorithmic Inflection of Russian and Generation of Grammatically Correct Text
review.abstract: We present a deterministic algorithm for Russian inflection. This algorithm is implemented in a publicly available web-service www.passare.ru which provides functions for inflection of single words, word matching and synthesis of grammatically correct Russian text. The inflectional functions have been tested against the annotated corpus of Russian language OpenCorpora.

metadata.title: THE ALGORITHMIC INFLECTION OF RUSSIAN AND GENERATION OF GRAMMATICALLY CORRECT TEXT

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Automatic superimposition of words into a natural language is necessary for a variety of theoretical and applied purposes such as parsing, topic and question generation [3], speech recognition and synthesis, machine translation [13], tagset design [17], information retrieval [12], content analysis, etc. Various approaches to automatic superimposition have been used to address certain aspects of superimposition [5, 23] in predefined languages [6, 8, 9, 16, 19] or in an unspecified language [7]. Despite significant advances in the field [16, 21, 22], automatic superimposition is still a problem of formidable complexity in the world.

sections.heading: 2. Algorithms and implementation
sections.text: The web service passare.ru offers a multitude of functions for the flexibilization of single Russian words, word matching and synthesis of grammatically correct text. In particular, the flexibilization of a Russian noun by number and case, the flexibilization of a Russian adjective by number, gender and case, the flexibilization of a Russian adverbs by degree of comparison is implemented. The Russian verb is the part of the speech whose terminology is by far the most complicated in the language. The presented algorithm offers the flexibilization of a Russian verb by tense, person, number and gender. It also allows to form the unpronounceable forms of a verb and to produce the imperative forms of a verb. Furthermore, the functions for the formation and inflection of active present and past participations are realized. Passive present participation is the only verb not currently supported by the website.

sections.text: Although all the functions of the website www.passare.ru - manually by selecting options and entering words with the respective terms (1st person; 3rd person; entering the parameters of a text to be created automatically; API-based automatic access is activated to speed up the work with large amounts of data; the details of API access to the main functions are to be recorded as a follow-up function.Interface: socketip: 46.173.208.127 Port: 9999 $$$Character encoding: UTF8To access a function, you must connect to the server, send a query string ending with the zero byte, get the response string that ends with the zero byte and closes the connection. The API-accessible functions of the website provide the applicability of the following parts of the speech: verb (ru verb) with the arguments: verb (the infinitive); person; gender; nooun (us) with the arguments: noun).

sections.heading: 6. Discussion
sections.text: There are several other approaches to automating Russian inflection and synthesis of grammatically correct Russian texts, e.g. [14, 16]. In addition, numerous programs attempt to automate a certain part of the language or the synthesis of a document with a rigid predefined structure [4]. Judging by publicly available information, most of these programs make use of extensively annotated corpora, which can fail if the word to be bent is sufficiently different from the elements in the databases. However, due to numerous irregularities in the Russian language, several lists of unusual linguistic objects (such as the list of unclinicable nouns or the list of verbs with strongly irregular English forms, see Fig. 1) have been compiled and used throughout the code. Whenever possible, rational descriptions of exceptional cases have been used to minimize the number of elements in such lists.
